docs.lead_paragraph: Parents who lost their only children in the Sichuan quake are having new babies, but anger still festers.

headline.main: Year After China Quake, New Births, Old Wounds
headline.print_headline: A Year After China’s Quake, New Lives Can’t Heal Old Wounds

docs.snippet: Parents who lost their only children in the Sichuan quake are having new babies, but anger still festers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Just 45 days old and swaddled in pink, Sang Ruifeng already has a purpose in life: to bring to justice those responsible for the death of his 11-year-old brother. Ruifeng will have to ensure, his father said, that the Chinese government gives a full accounting for why thousands of students died in school collapses during the earthquake that devastated southwest China one year ago. The brother that Ruifeng never knew was among 126 students crushed to death in Fuxin No. 2 Primary School outside this lush farming town.

headline.main: A Year After China's Quake, New Lives Can't Heal Old Wounds

docs.lead_paragraph: In the comments here last week, several of you asked about miscarriage: Why won't people stop saying "you can try again soon"? What is the "right" amount of grief? Are there more miscarriages now or does it just seem that way? What to tell the children about the baby who will not be?
docs.abstract: Questions about miscarriage, and advice on how to cope.
docs.snippet: Questions about miscarriage, and advice on how to cope.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama has said he will abolish the 16-year-old "don't ask, don't tell" policy, which allows gays and lesbians to serve in the military only if they do not disclose their sexual orientation. Nationwide, polls show that a majority of Americans support lifting the ban on openly gay members of the military. But support in the military's ranks and among retired officers is mixed. While several prominent retired generals and admirals have urged a repeal, others have said that allowing openly gay people to join the service would hurt recruiting and retention.

headline.main: In the Barracks, Out of the Closet

docs.abstract: How easy will it be to integrate openly gay and lesbian service members into the U.S. military?
docs.snippet: How easy will it be to integrate openly gay and lesbian service members into the U.S. military?
